hints.content: Equivalent fractions cover the same area of the whole.

Let's represent $\dfrac{2}{3}$ using a visual model.

![rectangle with 2 of 3 equal parts shaded, with each part labeled 1 third.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/f4c867d5e2196c4febd679e4b81ff39e677aeeb4)

We need $4$ parts in the equivalent fraction to cover the same area as $\dfrac{2}{\blueD{3}}$.

![rectangle with 2 of 3 equal parts shaded, with each part labeled 1 third.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/f4c867d5e2196c4febd679e4b81ff39e677aeeb4)  
![same-sized rectangle with 4 of an unknown number of equal parts shaded, each labeled 1 over unknown number.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/abf8c5b8eb780336f389488ffd3fed76c6538020)

How many equal parts should the equivalent fraction have?

We need $\maroonD{6}$ equal parts per whole.

![rectangle with 2 of 3 equal parts shaded, with each part labeled 1 third.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/f4c867d5e2196c4febd679e4b81ff39e677aeeb4)  
![same-sized rectangle with 2 of 6 equal parts shaded, with each part labeled 1 sixth.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/3455bd7cf49f4f99e66f7ea1e1ecc2a92ec44621)

 $\dfrac{4}{\maroonD{6}} = \dfrac{2}{3}$

question.content:
**What value of $k$ makes the equation true?**

 $\dfrac{4}{k} = \dfrac{2}{3}$

$k=$ [[â˜ƒ numeric-input 1]]
